Overall, an awesome series. A must watch this season for sure! :D

Yes, I believe this show is not worth watching. Is everything bad about it? No. I am absolutely impressed by the art in the opener. Never did I think an animator would accurately draw what it would actually look like for someone to play those instruments at that exact point in the music (check out the covers people do for the op). 
Anyway putting that aside, three main problems occurred for me when watching this show.
1. Concept. It is a show about a music group getting together to play music, but a good portion, and I mean every scene except for a few, have verylittle to do with playing music.

2.Origin of Entertainment. From what I could get, enjoyment came from either looking at cute girls doing cute things, slice of life comedy, or both. 

3. Characters. Look at the characters at the beginning of the show. Now look at them in the end, have they changed? No. 


My biggest concern was the concept behind the show. Answer these statements with only agree or disagree. These girls are making a band. They get together to play music. The best "concert" scene of the show is the opening. Now stop. Let's think for a moment. This show is about a group of girls forming a band and playing music, but the only time they are actually performing seems to be the opening of the show. I think my point is fairly clear, though I may be mistaking it and it is really just a slice of life anime centered around music. I guess it would make sense as it would avoid making it another Lucky Star (I also did not enjoy this either since it reminded me too heavily of the fact that I could be doing the same exact things the characters were doing rather than watching it). But even as a slice of life, the entertainment, comedy, was too heavily focused on the moe factor, which brings me to my next point.


Why do I want to watch cutesy anime girls talk about starting a band but never actually play music? The kind of entertainment you can get from this show is what I can get from looking up moe pictures online. It is probably different for everyone else, but that is what I assumed was the entertainment. There were some points where the slice of life did come into play, but I felt the slice of life was never truly entertaining nor funny. Sorry, I don't like watching the same gags slice of life tends to offer.


Finally, the characters. Most storytelling in any shape or form always has some kind of character development which changes the character's personality, ESPECIALLY in slice of life. The reason is that CHARACTER DEVELOPMENT IS A KEY ELEMENT OF MOST ENTERTAINMENT MEDIUMS USING STORYTELLING. Even if the characters supposedly got better at playing together as a band and learned their instruments, it was completely irrelevant to personalities of  the characters as they never really changed. This alone would not be a problem of there was something to be had from the  interactions between the characters, but I came to realize that the interactions were a little too realistic for me, as in, I was constantly asking myself, "Hey, you could be doing this too, right? Why are you watching this then? Why are their interactions completely on the level of being plausible in reality minus a few things?" 


These interactions may have been to convey a sense of realism, but to me, they conveyed reality, which if you use anime as a form of entertainment to take your mind off of reality for a little. There were some moments that are clearly near impossible to find in your daily life, but the overall feel of the show, the entertainment, and the goal chasing are so easy to replicate with friends in real life that you might as well do it yourself. 


Thus, as much as I would like to rave about the animation, the meat of the show is just too little for me to actually enjoy.


To break it down:

Pros:

+amazing opener animation

+a good representation of putting plan to action(minus some spots)

+enjoyable music


Cons:

-music was very limited

-little to no character development

-no need to watch the show for the same entertainment

-depended on moe for entertainment


I know there are some people with opposing opinions, so if wish to refute me, feel free. I might give this show another chance if there is enough opposition, but for now, this is an accurate representation of my thoughts for the K-On

I've found K-On to be a fantastic light-hearted story with a refreshing lack of drama.  I think the reason it's stood out so much for me this season is that the carefree aesthetic of the show is really quite refreshing.  With other hard-hitting drama shows like Eden of the East are building tension and suspense through the whole episode, K-On gives an opposite approach, and really doesn't push any sort of seriousness on the viewer.  
Ignoring the parameter of anime, even in American television shows these days, it seems like everything is over-dramatized and so many inconsequential scenarios are built up tobe a big deal.  In K-On, nothing is a big deal - it's seriously just a half-hour spot of relaxing, fun enjoyment.  This is the charm of K-On for me.


If you're looking for excitement on a Gurren-Laggan-esque plane, K-On is not going to give it to you.  If you're looking for a panty-shot every other frame and an outlet to swoon over scantily clad girls, then K-On isn't going to give it to you (despite the entire cast being female, all of whom are absolutely adorable).  


K-On is by no means a jaw-dropper, but there is a certain calm aesthetic about that I've never really seen in a show before.  It feels good to watch a group of best friends getting along and playing music (or more often, eating pastries and drinking tea), so if you're looking for an easy-to-watch show with no hidden, analyzable motifs that simply exists to put a smile on your face, I couldn't recommend anything more highly than K-On.

Okay, firstly to start off, I was persuaded by a friend to watch this and downloaded in batch so I sort of felt responsible to sit through the entire thing.
To start off. I'm not much of a writer. Its my second attempt at a review (first being completely shot down and its kind of an embarrassment now that I think about it...) So I'm going to try to follow a template of sorts with 
the help of that rating bar at the top.
To open. K-On! was a drag. The fact I even mention that bit at the top pretty much makes it seem like Iforced myself through it. And I did. Its supposed to be a slice of life anime, usually slice of life anime starts off with a slow pace and work on getting you to like the character. And then quickly go into a deeper plot that keeps you wanting to know more. But it 


Story : K-On! has no story. Okay maybe that is exaggeration but it is close enough. The general plot is about 4 girls who join a school's music club to save it. Thats pretty much solved in the first few episodes and after that plot is thrown off a cliff. Then there is the theme! Music. Which seems to have been more of an excuse to start the series off rather than and the actual point of the story, there are a few points in the story where music is implemented but it feels forced and they are pretty forgettable. Most of the time is spent in their music room eating cake and listening to them talk about mundane things like in Lucky Star. The only difference being that its not funny. A plot is supposed to be about problems and solving them, but everything in this anime seems to be just work out. Yui can't play any instruments, she also can't read notes. So somebody tell me how this fits the realism part of "slice of life" anymore...


Art : This part of K-On! is what people love or hate. The art can be seen by some as simplistic to add to the light-hearted feel of the anime. Other can say it is poorly drawn with little attention to detail and makes it feel unprofessional. I go with the second view. The manga's cover illustrations were pretty good though. Although that is off topic.


Sound : Pretty much the only song that I found mildly appealing was the first OP Cagayake Girls!, the ED Don't Say Lazy seemed to have generated quite some interest from the fanbase but I wasn't my taste. The insert songs slotted in here and there in episodes were dry and made me feel like an idiot listening to them. They really should know when to limit the entire moe moe kyun thing here. It seems to be their only selling point. I already compared it to one show with Aya Hirano so might as well again. Even the God Knows bit from Haruhi alone is more enjoyable than any of the songs here. And it wasn't even a music anime.


Character : At the start there is a little bit of development with the four girls. But after that it pretty much centers on Yui being a complete retard. I would normally say this would be cliched but most idiot anime characters actually have good points at times that redeem them. Yui fails to do so.


Enjoyment : It seemed interesting at first. But it quickly went into the gutter with the originality and actual story. I'm guessing if you are that kind of person you would like this anime, but for myself I found it to be a drag and uninteresting.

Another Robert's Too Late Reviews is here to blast into your eyes! Today we're going to be talking about the well-known series K-On! First few details to note is we're working the dub, and we'll be including both season 1 and 2 and Live House, basically everything but the movie as they all have a similar theme, tone, appearance, and style. The short of it is that I found some points a little lacking with this series, yet the overall upbeat and fun presentation really made up for its missteps and made it an anime to remember! Even though this anime doesn't give me roomfor my philosophical musings, still read on for the more mundane details, and to see if HTT makes the RTLR wall of musical madness! (You might be surprised!)


Story: 8

The story is your usual slice-of-life fare, whether it be school festivals, studying for exams, trips to the beach, what have you, nothing we've not seen done a billion times before. In the first season there's an opening arc concerning saving the Light Music Club but those quickly dissipate, and the only other overriding theme becomes hijinks based on the girls' various personalities. In the second season there is hints about the concern for the future of the Club, but they never really go anywhere, and are hand waved away by the end. 


The weakness in the story starts early, with our main, Yui, joining the Light Music Club rather by mistake than anything else. She has no apparent musical experience, yet is able to pick up the guitar and basically rock out on it from nearly day one. She is at first the only guitarist, and is able to play lead well enough to impress a crowd. As I've mentioned in other reviews such as Hibike Euphonium (another great musical anime) I'm a veteran musician, and not to brag, but one blessed with a good bit of natural talent. I tried to learn the guitar after knowing how to read music, and being proficient with several wind instruments and playing in general, and let me tell ya, it takes more than just a few weeks of practice to play a guitar at a level that doesn't just make all the alleycats yowl, let alone impress a crowd. Yui's sudden skill on an axe is wildly inaccurate from my experience. 


This is compounded by the fact that Yui is a total airhead, who seems to be doing good to remember her own name, let alone chords, scales, or even rudimentary musical theory. In fact later in season 1 and throughout the rest of the show, when the second guitarist Azusa joins, who in fact is a practiced guitarist, she regularly comments on how clueless Yui is regarding playing, yet seems to always jam out when the time comes. I wish getting on stage was enough to turn me from fumbling Bob to Jimi Hendrix. Guess I'm not Yui though. 


Another interesting point is that this anime is about the band formed in the Light Music Club, and how they play several functions here and there, yet is mainly NOT about the music. If you were expecting Love Live or Idolmaster where the music is actually performed, you're going to be a bit disappointed. They occasionally play a hook or a bit more, but we're never privy to any full blown playing outside of the theme songs. In fact, second guitarist Azusa's biggest personality feature throughout the series is that she is a serious musician and the band NEVER practices. She grumbles about that all the way to basically the end, constantly amazed at how the band comes together at crunch time. I am too, honestly. 


With all that complaining, how can I rate this as a 9 overall? Because in spite of these flaws, the show is an absolute blast, with fairly rapid fire comedy sequences, playing on the personalities of the various girls and their relations to each other. The stereotypical personalities appear, but they work well, and put together in the manner that K-On arranges them just works so much better than one might expect. The day to day hijinks might be a bit predictable, but they are pulled with aplomb and often brought me to literally laugh out loud. 


In the slice-of-life genre, you need characters to be memorable to remain viable. Without characters that stick with us, there's little point in watching as the events are always the same, with only slight variations. We know there's going to be a school event or festival of some kind, there's going to be a winter/Christmas episode, we know there's going to be an exam show, etc. If you don't have characters that handle these in unique ways, you're going to have the show get lost in the shuffle. I think of shows such as Maria-sama ga Miteru and their serious interpersonal relationships in this genre, or perhaps the lusty and silly Yamada from Yamada's First Time. Thing is, you have to have characterizations that we want to remember to work.


K-On does this, with rapid fire Ritsu, or worrying Azusa, or scaredy cat Mio, or rich and naive Mugi, and so forth. These girls, interacting together, equal more than the sum of their parts. They end up being more than silly girls doing silly things, and rise up and leave their marks on us as an audience. Their takes on each other are also interesting, as they learn and grow in their friendships. A few of them have been friends for a long time, but not all, the main Yui, and the second guitarist Azusa are new recruits when they join, and they are a blast to watch as they interact and discover things about their new friends. 


Rounded out with some interesting side characters, such as the teacher with a heavy metal past, a student council president that seems to secretly want to rock, and a little sister who inherited her own brains and Yui's as well, and you have a cast that carries infectious energy and makes the whole retread of slice-of-life milestones a new and fun experience. 


Art: 7

The only thing that saved this from being just 'fair' is the instruments. The instruments look very good, are well drawn. I love K-On greatly, but beautifully animated, it is not. There are lots of spots with very awkward animations and odd looking elements. Hands especially seem to be a difficult thing for the artists, as there are several instances I saw where hands looked kind of deformed or out of shape. The girls are all unique enough looking, but rather plain looking. They get the job done, no doubt, but they are just not all that pleasing to the eye, the instruments being the exception. Again, this is a section that becomes less relevant as the characters and comedy bits come into play and draw our focus away from how it all looks to how fun the girls are. 


Sound: 8

What playing we do hear the girls do in the series is well enough done, and a lot of fun to jam to, but it could use to have more of it. They mention several song titles throughout the series, and I always wanted to hear them, but never did. I kept thinking, cmon throw me a bone and actually play 'Rice is a Side Dish'! Alas it was not to be. 


Speaking of playing, the themes are an absolute blast. The first theme opens with this really heavy sounding guitar riff and then splashes into Yui's high pitched singing which you do NOT expect. I was thinking Judas Priest, and I got Japanese teen. It is so funny it's cool. The first opener for season 2, Go Go Maniac, is even better, as we get a nearly rapping Yui throwing down. The final opener is good as well. 


Even better than the opener is all three closers. They are sang by Mio, who by far has the superior vocals and the songs are not silly, at least in presentation, if not in lyrics, and are presented as legitimate rocking songs. They work well. I really liked 'Listen' the first closer on the second season. They were all enjoyable, however. 


The voice work in the dub was pretty well done. Ritsu sounded really bright, Mio's deeper voice is fitting for her leadership-like role, and Mugi sounds as sweet as she acts. Yui's voice is very close to the annoying level, but she never quite steps over the line. Gets real close at times, however.  Other characters are appropriately done, Student Council member Nodaka stands out as being well played to me. The teacher/advisor for the band is played well also, old enough to be believable and humorous when she does her bits, but young enough not to be totally unacceptable when she speaks of her past as a rocker. 


Character: 9

Here's where we get into the fun. The characters are what sets this apart from any number of forgettable slice-of-life anime. Yui, our main, is completely airheaded and scattered-brained. She is a lot like Kotori of Love Live if you are familiar. Yui is forever forgetting things, sometimes even her guitar (which she's named Gita) when it comes time to go to practice or to play a gig. An aside, the girl just starts guitar and grabs up a badass Les Paul? Damn girl! She relies on everyone else, and her own carefree attitude to carry her through, and for the most part, this approach works. She does seem to be serious about playing well enough with the band as to not embarrass herself or her friends. She puts her heart into things, but unfortunately her mind tends to wander. She's the butt of a lot of jokes, especially from Ritsu. She can be a bit hard to watch sometimes, as her antics ride the line of getting old, but she balances it out mostly. 


Ritsu the drummer is bright, cheery mostly, and is the quick witted one of the group, always handy with a joke or snide comment. She's also the one burning with determination, and once she decides on a course of action, she pushes through until her goals are achieved, whether it be playing a new song, or going to the beach to play in the sun. She tends to fall more towards Yui in the fact that she's pretty carefree, and is loathe to do any paperwork, but isn't quite so forgetful and turned around as Yui. 


Mio is the bassist who is the unofficial leader, the responsible one, and the one most likely to freak out. She has stage fright, she gets scared over the littlest thing (much to Ritsu's delight) and is the one that advocates the responsible course of action. She often is on the same side of issues as Azusa, even though the responsible pair is outnumbered by the others. Mio sees to the others enough to get everything done that needs to, and kind of holds the ship together as Yui and Ritsu steer it off into the great blue yonder. 


Mugi is the keyboardist who comes from a super rich family, and is the typical naive and sweet girl. She brings tea and dishes that royal families across the world use, putting them out nonchalantly as if she was using Spongebob paper cups. She also has little 'real' world experience, being awed by fast food and shopping in a 'regular' store and such. She's kind to a fault but always tends to fall with the airheads of the group in any situation requiring input, much to Mio's exasperation. 


Later in season 1 the band adds Azusa, a girl a year younger than the rest of the band who is the straight man for Yui and Ritsu's comedy and bits. Azusa is that band member that's always yelling about practicing, going on and on about technique and skill, and being a general pain. If you've ever played in a band, whether it be a rock band, or even a wind and brass band, you should know at least one, if not more, people who fit this very role. Azusa is thwarted as always by Yui and Ritsu and their irresponsible ways. Azusa even comes to points where she considers quitting the band, but finds that her friendships are too important, and the fact the girls can perform when crunch time comes convinces her to stay. 


The supporting character Ui, Yui's sister (no typo) is the real support behind Yui, making sure she is well taken care of at all times. Ui is younger than her guitar jamming sister, but acts much more like a big sister or even mother for the errant high schooler. She supports the band in general, and is good friends with Azusa, being the same age. In fact it is slightly hinted that she might well follow Yui's footsteps in the band as well, after Yui graduates. 


The final character to mention is the funny faculty advisor, Ms. Sawako Yamanaka, or as the girls call her, Sawa-chan. She has history with the Club, as a band member herself back when she was in school, though this is something she's desperate to hide. She also gets very wrapped up in their doings, making them costumes and being a bit of a comedy player, often acting as a foil for Ritsu, and vice versa. She's a lot of fun and has a few really great episodes as well. 


Enjoyment: 9

This is where my overall comes from, if it's not apparent, I just adore K-On, because it is more than just a slice-of-life, and more than just a music anime. It's both neither those things, and both stereotypically so at times. Its not all that great animated but yet is fun and easy enough on the eyes. The music isn't played as much as it should, but is present enough to give a good feel for who the band is, and is upbeat and fun when you hear it. This anime is somehow its parts, and yet more at the same time. It's a blast to watch. I can't explain it really in words. After coming off heavy fare like some of my latest watches, and prior to another 'heavier' series I have coming soon, it's a big break to see something light and fluffy. This is exactly what it seems, fluffy show for fluffy viewing.


We'll get back to the seriousness real soon, I promise. This review feels light to me but then again, K-On is a light show, about the Light Music Club, so it works I guess. If you like musical type shows like Love Live or Idolmaster you might be at home here. If you like cute girls doing cute things like Girls und Panzer, you might like what you see. If you just want to watch something without having to think too hard, just laugh and kick back, check this one out! As for the RTLR wall, no one from the show made the wall at all! Not a single one! In fact then ENTIRE band scored 7 inch figures on the shelves of anime goodness, a much higher honor! Two thumbs up!

Looking at the score, you might think I belong to the 'Anti K-ON' fraction. I am not necessarily a hater, since in terms of slice-of-life genre, K-ON is better than most anime out there. 
If you want to look at this series on the positive light, think of it as a filler. Think of it as a plotless story with cute girls gathering and playing around. Think not of it as a story about the birth of a band.
There is almost no character development nor conclusion. K-ON simply offers light and fluffy heart-warming skits for your pleasure. Yet, the characters of K-ON sufficiently meet theexpectation, especially for the male audiences. I mean, who will not be enthralled by seeing a girl as cute and seductive as Mio? Will there be any lolicon (sorry) out there be not thrilled with Asuza?\n\n
How unrealistic and forgettable K-ON is, it is still an adequate entertainment to spend your free time. It is nothing sort of Beck, which is indeed a true music anime. It wants to achieve the excellence of the likes of Lucky Star and Azumanga Daioh, yet it is still missing an emotional element that all otakus out there need: the interaction with the audience. K-ON never attempts to break the fourth wall and make fun of popular culture. Its music is okay for the standard of J-pop but not that impressive.\n\n
Overall, it is 'easy come, easy go' for the five girls of the Light Music Group. Nothing more, nothing less.

K-ON! First caught my attention by it's adorable artwork and it's big fanbase. Though it didn't turn out as good as thought it might.
Story: I gave the story of K-ON! a 5. Mediocre. The story revolves around a girl who decides to make a band with a few new friends she has made after joining the music club-but she can't even play anything yet. The story follows her as she learns to play guitar and has fun with her friends. And there's not that much else to it. The story can get boring at times and tends to repeat itself after a while. So overallthe story isn't the best factor to this anime.


Art: As I said before the artwork was what originally got my attention. The artwork is cute but they all tend to have the same face and there's nothing very unique for each character. So I gave the art an 8. It's very good and cute but if you don't like moe sort of art than I suggest you don't watch this.


Sound: I gave the sound a 9. The sound is probably the best thing about this anime. The backround music isn't too distracting and it fits the anime's mood. Since this anime is all about a girl who joins a band, there is a lot of music that they perform. It's fun and cute to listen to so if you are looking for some girly japanese pop singing, you might want to listen to these songs they perform on your own time instead of going through with watching this anime. As for the voice acting-it is very moe and they all tend to sound the same. None of the characters voices are too high-pitched which can sometimes end up happening when you watch an anime that has cute or moe characters.


Character: The character category got a 4 from me. The character design on this anime was horrible. Although the artwork is cute, they all have the exact same faces and characteristics. There isn't much individuality in this anime. As for the characters' personalities, they each have their thing but nothing spectacular. There's the rich girl, the loud girl, the shy, big-boobed girl, and the confused, innocent protagonist. Nothing new here.


Enjoyment: This anime is a boring slice-of-life. I found none of the jokes or experiences in K-ON! very funny. The most enjoyment I got out of it was listening to the music they performed and maybe the few jokes here and there. But over-all the enjoyment section gets a 5 from me.


So over-all I would give it a 5. It's really no the best anime out there. Though it has a large fanbase, I wouldn't recommend watching this anime. It bored me to death and I don't think it's worth wasting time on.

"FUWA FUWA TIME!"
What compels us, as a human race, to create music? What gives us the motivation and encouragement to create audible works of art?
Any one of us (musically-inclined, anyway) would say the joy comes from the instrument itself - that creating unique sound different from the human voice gives us power and creativity in a form never known before. Plus playing music can be fun and enjoyable, a way to relax and keep the day young.
In K-ON!, this is just the opposite. The characters typically tried NOT to play, except for a few select times. And when they did, it was never serious norenjoyable. In fact, the story seemed to revolve around that there was no story. Interesting paradox. Throughout the story (actually, it's more like pieces of a story - random side-notes and whatnot that leave you sort of hanging at the end), Mio, Yui, Ritsu, and Mugi tend not to do much besides eat and procrastinate. There, I said it. This is the perfect show if you like to procrastinate (and don't you be saying you don't. Everyone enjoys avoiding work from time to time). \n\n
It does become serious at certain points, and the characters do develop (more or less) slightly. And what's not to like about their rock-n-roll style that incorporates girly lyrics? I'm a guy, and I enjoyed the songs, finding myself at least humming or tapping my foot to their surprisingly catchy tunes. The OP and ED are quite good - the songs have made their way onto my Ipod, and I thoroughly enjoy humming the tune whenever I'm thinking hard. The light-hearted style of the songs keep me coming back for more.\n\n
This is one of those slice-of-life anime, with many references to moe and whatnot. I'm not saying that's bad, but if you're not really into no story and pointless segments of video that don't really seem to tie into the main plot all that much, this isn't the anime for you. I did enjoy it, however, despite my disappointment of the overall story. At the end of every episode, you get this kind of happy-giddy feeling, like doing something crazy for the first time. You simply become addicted, and you want some more K-ON! to fill your hungry soul.\n\n
Once again, the strong suit of this anime is the sound - I cannot stress that enough. The songs are good overall and the OP and ED are great - check them out, at least. I know how it feels to pick up an instrument for the first time, and it's a one-of-a-kind sort of feeling, one that leaves you standing there with infinite possibilites of what to do. K-ON! does seem to nail this feeling, and leave you with a happy go lucky attitude at the end. However, viewer discretion is advised: watch for the moe!

If someone were to ask the typical anime fan what do they think of K-On? The typical response what would be phrases such as, “ohh that moeshit” or “that kyoani bullshit that began the cancerous product known as moe”. To a certain extent they are right. While K-On itself is not an atrocious anime to watch,(although it might be depending on how much you can tolerate cute girls) it is no lie that K-On is the title that really brought the moe trend into the forefront and is the trend that has shaped the identity of modern anime. And it’s not that this trend wasn’tpopular before K-On’s domination of sales charts. Kyoto Animation has an infamous track record for taking advantage of this trend's popularity to fill their pockets. The success of anime such as Air, Kanon, Clannad and The melancholy of Haruhi Suzumiya have proved the formula’s success before K-On and it convinced Kyoto Animation that this was certainly the next big thing in the industry and they have every right to take advantage of it. Despite what many people believe about Kyoto Animation shows from a critical standpoint nobody can deny their financial success. 





And K-On fits exactly into that category. It was made for more for the purpose of making money rather than receiving numerous amounts of awards and basked in critical acclaim. There is nothing wrong with that. After all, anime is a business and making money is just the normal procedure that defines every business. K-On doesn’t do much to separate itself from the typical moeblob though. Throughout the course of the show it barely takes itself seriously. The majority of the run time the characters are just participating in goofy events or drinking tea making fun of each other. The tone of the show is consistently goofy throughout and whatever potential is there for some character drama and conflict comes out as a joke more than anything else. It would be a ridiculous to even say this show has a plot,  it COULD have had one if it decided to take whatever little plot elements it focused on them in a much more serious manner by placing more significance on them and using them as a wat to initiate conflict to give the characters some ACTUAL challenges




There is not much to really say about the characters in a general sense, since they are only defined by a couple of gimmicks and don’t offer any real substance. I can’t really say much when it comes to the tropes of moe since I have little to no prior experience with it before watching K-On. But the endearing and extremely likable cast helped redeem K-On from it’s lack of character depth. Their cast chemistry is cute and their personalities complement each other well and as a result create some funny and sweet moments throughout the series. It is hard to pinpoint which characters the show tries to focus on as there is not really much to say in terms of characterization or development and the whole cast is usually on screen at once and no one really has the individual spotlight for a whole episode.  Since the cast is small I will personally describe each characters personality and traits:






-Yui is very carefree, easy going and is often the biggest comedic relief out of the cast. She is often being clumsy and making a fool out of herself in front of the other characters. Another thing that adds to her humorous character is her knack for often not reading instructions before trying out things and instead prefers to rely on her hunch or intuition. She is easily distracted and tends to try and find any excuse possible to not practice and only feels motivated to play her instrument if she eats a fill of cake.


-Ritsu is the character who is always looking to make fun of  everyone around her through sarcastic puns and humour. She is the biggest entertainer of the group and my favourite for her very comical personality and wittiness. Similarly to Yui she is easy going and upbeat but doesn’t share Yui’s clumsiness and is more composed than she is.


Mio- Mio always tries to keep the group grounded to reality when they continue to be senselessly stupid and reminding them more often than not of their obligation to practice. She is the most serious and mature member of the group and doesn’t participate in her friends’ witty banter’ or routine of ‘milk and cookies’ as much as they do. Most of Ristu’s continual teasing of Mio is how prone she is to getting embarrassed when she is put into the spotlight as highlighted when pressure is put on her to sing the lyrics during performances.


Tsumugi- Tsumugi is a lot more passive and quiet in comparison to the other members of the group and doesn’t really talk much. Similarly to Mio she is a little more level headed and mature than Yui and Ritsu. It feels as if she does not get as much screen time or focus compared to the other characters and as a result she is a lot duller. She is the most cheerful character in the show and often thinks about other people before herself. Because of her dullness her character doesn’t have any flair compared to the other characters. Ritsu has sarcasm which makes her witty. Yui is extremely clumsy which makes her cute and Mio is a lot more responsible compared to the rest. Tsumugi feels as if she is just there to give them free holiday resorts and supply the daily dose of tea for me.


All the characters in the show are 1-D that can be described with a few words and nothing more.  The show attempts to freshen things by adding a new character to the main and it certainly worked. The new addition to the squad served as a counter to the ridiculous theatrics the main cast engage in and is someone who takes their music a whole lot more seriously in the same vein as Mio. This made for some nice short lived conflict but it just wasn’t taken seriously enough for me to care and it ultimately proved to be pointless. 




It isn’t an easy task to try and describe what the story of K-On is in multiple paragraphs because there really isn’t one. Apart from a squad of cute girls drinking tea and occasionally playing music no other story elements such as romance or drama are present. And despite what many people say about K-On being a musical and that it’s all about practicing to achieve your dreams, K-On lacks any sort of focus on these elements to even take them seriously as they all feel like backdrops rather than the spotlight. There was also potential for K-On to be a story about fitting in and making new friends. Both of these themes have been done countless times in anime with a high school setting but it would have been a good addition to spice things up and give the show some kind of plot. But K-On decided to just frolic around and not take any of its potential story elements seriously. If the show itself doesn’t take these elements seriously, why should I? It would have given the show an extra layer and more substance if it spent some time taking the music aspect of the show seriously or adding some high school romance. Having some form of conflict would have made the characters feel a little more authentic and not just being ‘moeblobs’ that can be described by a few overused tropes and enjoyed on a superficial level.



K-On certainly is enjoyable when looked at only on the surface. The character designs are fairly generic but are still attractive to look at thanks to the excessive cuteness that Kyoani put into them and their good artwork in general. The backgrounds are plain and do not offer anything in the grand scheme of things but still are some nice eye candy. The visuals are colorful and fit well with the goofy tone of the show. 


Now the only aspect of K-On where I could REALLY give the show any credit for is its music. The fast paced j-pop songs are quite catchy and I even re-listened to them a few times. The sound directing all round is very good and I found both the opening and ending to be nice to listen to. But those catchy songs were far and few between. For a show that is meant to be a musical they certainly didn’t have enough of them to warrant it being called that. But nonetheless the songs were enjoyable even if they were far and few between. The OST for K-On was simultaneously upbeat and goofy, which fit the mood of what was happening on screen and helped put an even bigger smile on my face than I already had when watching comedic scenes. Other than that it was forgettable and didn’t have any other impact.




Despite what I may think of K-On critically, I cannot deny that I enjoyed it for what it was and it helped open my mind a little to the over saturated genre of ‘cute girls doing cute things’. When I scroll through seasonal charts and look at all the countless ‘CGDCT’ titles made, one of the first things that strikes me is how low budget and lifeless they look. It’s as if they were made for the soul purpose of barely breaking even. But I can appreciate the fact that Kyoani give their generic moe shows life and look as if they are putting effort into it. They don’t want it to just break even, they want it to demolish the sales charts and they have succeeded on more than one occasion. K-On has a good sense of fun, an endearing cast and some nice music, but that’s all I can really say about it. It is extremely shallow and offers nothing but shits and giggles. If you are looking for an anime to wind down to you after a long day of work, or something that will make you forget about your shit life than I suggest giving K-On a try. Despite all the things I heard about moe being cancerous, for what K-On as, it wasn’t all that bad. Watching ‘cute girls doing cute things won’t be everyone’s thing and it isn’t my favorite thing to watch either, but this one is worth a shot for the fun of it. 


Overall:5.5/10

This is a great guilty pleasure. Really.
If you've seen scanlations of the manga, this is essentially an expanded version of the 8 panel strip with real music and less raunchiness. (sorry, no Mio cameltoe or sensei boob grabs iin this one).
The plot is simple. Four girls start a keion (popular music) club. 
The characters equally simple: Yui: klutz, goofy, lazy. Mio: shy, tsundere, moe. Ritsu: token tomboy. Mugi: token rich girl lesbo. Throw in bipolar sensei and painfully cute nee-chan and you have most of the cast. 
With that said,. the characters are lovable, the animation style is very lively with evocative gestures (i.e. thecharacters don't just stand there and talk at each other, motionless), and everyone is so cute it'll either captivate you, give you cavities, or make you into a murderous psychopath.\n\n
There is no story. Does there have to be? It's a pure slice of life anime with humorous characters and scenarios. Nothing too original here. But it's funny to see the Japanese mention Jeff Beck or Hendrix, or that the girls' sensei is some death metal punk rocker.\n\n
There are original music pieces in the anime, and they actually make an effort to make it look and sound like they did their homework with the music, which sounds like typical bubblegum J-Pop. Thankfully it's not overdone, and comes across as endearing and neither bland or Kajiura-ish. No flourishing violins set to the backdrop of explosions and flying robots, thank god.\n\n
This is a simple anime, but it does all things well and comes across as very fun, harmless, and enjoyable. \n\n
And it's really hard not to love the characters.

K-On! offers you exactly what it says it will offer: moe, fluffiness, and music.
Every week, you get your serving of cuteness and some music. This is the kind of show where you don't have to watch it in high-brain-power mode. You can just chill, turn off your brain almost completely and still get the concept. There are moments in this show that will make you laugh and some that will nearly make you cry. 
Iif you are looking for in-depth character development in a series, K-On! will not exactly offer that to you. Ritsu, Mio, Mugi, Yui, and Azusa did have some character development butnot to the point where it will satisfy your need (most likely). Also, each character have their own interesting personalities that make the show even more enjoyable.\n\n
Although the show is named K-On! (keion for light music), you will not really get the hardcore music scenes and songs that you'd want. If you look at this show as a music club with 5 girls, you will be pretty much disappointed if you take it from that point of view. If you look it at the other way, 5 girls who come together because of music, you will not be disappointed.\n\n
In brief, I recommend K-On! if you're looking for a moe anime that will give you the lulz, but don't expect it to be really deep because its based after a 4-koma manga after all.
