The Story: 5/10
 	It’s freshman year and Yui coming to the realization that she hasn’t done a goddamn thing with her life, realizes it's time to shame up and join an after school activity. She becomes interested in the light music club thinking she could play the castanets, but boy was she wrong, but she still feels obligated to stay in the club, so after a bit of awkward peer pressure she decides to continue to be part of the Light Music Club and learn guitar so she can continue to eat the delicious dessert Tsumugi brings in every meeting. The pacing of the plotis pretty minimal and the actual story is pretty bare bones, with slice-of-life high school problems filling out the moments that aren’t holidays or concert performances. I doubt anyone is really looking for a gripping plot when watching K-On! anyways they’ll probably instead have a squuuuuuueeeeeegasm at how moe each member is,and over  just how darn quirky they are. With K-On! it isn’t about the destination, but just how many adorable moments one can squeeze out of 13 short episodes. 


Characters: 6/10


	First of all you got the MC, Yui Hirasawa she’s really naive and airheaded, but she can do great things if she puts her mind to it, oh she also loves sweets along with everyone else in the Light Music Club. Mio Akiyama is the bass player who is intelligent, shy, a bit of scaredy cat, and probably the most talented musician of the bunch, Tsumugi Kotobuki is the keyboardist, who’s thoughtful, nice, rich, and also a bit of an airhead (I feel like she is the least well-developed character of the group, although none of the main cast is all that well rounded). Ritsu Tainaka is the drummer and the club president, she’s a bit rough and is childhood friends with Mio, thought she acts really similar to Yui at times. Azusa Nakano is the final band member, and is the rhythm guitarist I assume. She’s a year younger than the rest of the members, and she is definitely the most serious of the bunch. I love her coming in, and being put off by all the tea drinking and cosplaying the LMC does during most practices, and I despised how they showered her with attention by forcing her to try on outfits and making cat noises it was pretty uncomfortable. 


Art: 7/10


 	The show looks well enough for being in the moe slice-of-life genre and a lot of shows that KyoAni does tends to look pretty gorgeous (like the first image result when you type in Sound! Euphonium Reina I mean, wow). Everything about the art design is either sufficient or god damn adorable. The animation on the other hand is average overall, even the band’s performances don’t look all that fluid or smooth. 


Music: 8/10


	K-On! doesn’t disappoint in the quality of the songs in the show, but I just wish that there was way more actually songs in the series, since I don’t remember very many. Both the opening and ending for season 1 are praiseworthy. The show is also pretty hard rock sounding during intro then blasts into a girly frilly rock song, that reflects that actual tone of subject matter of the show to a tee. It’s timid and precious at times, and then crescendos into a chorus of youthful exuberance  and rainbows and The Ending is exhilarating and really gives off the vibe that they are an actual rock band, and not some tea drinking amateur high school band. Also the costume design and transitions showing each band member and their instruments are really sleek and eye-popping. I love both the opening and ending for season one, and are my favorite parts of the series for sure.


Enjoyment: 7/10


Despite the rarely seen plot, K-On! can actually be addicting in short bursts, It’s like the sweets the girls devour every afternoon, it’s best short and sweet, and if you too many in a single time it will leave you with a heartache. It’s sort of the the anime equivalent of Animal Crossing, I mean it’s nice to check in every once in awhile to see how your town and neighbors are doing, but there is only so much you can do in a single visit, and can get boring and drawn out pretty quickly. The best this for sure is the music, and if anything just check out the openings and the ending for season one, and if your interest in the characters then watch the show, but if it those don’t do anything for you then don’t bother with K-On!.

As you may have heard, K-On is a pretty cute show. If you hadn't heard...it is. As many others have said, don't watch it if you don't like cutesy kinds of shows. 
K-On is the first full season of anime I've ever completed. I'd seen pictures from it around and I finally decided to watch it to see what it was about. I was pleasantly surprised. 
K-On a feel-good kind of show. It'll make you smile. There's nothing too serious going on. There's nothing perverted. It's good clean fun. It would be hard to get offended watching this show, no matter who you are. It'ssilly high school girls being silly. That's an aspect I really love about the show. It lets girls be girls. It's not trying to turn them into something they're not. They're young girls having fun together, facing joys and struggles in a school club. The lack of drama might be unrealistic, but is nonetheless refreshing. 


The characters are all adorable and unique. I personally could identify with different aspects of each character, but I'm sure many people identify specifically with one or the other since the girls are all very different. Mugi, Mio, and Azusa are all shy, but in their own way. Mugi is content being quiet. Mio is more serious and paralyzed by embarrassment. Azusa is reserved and always wants to do what is proper. And then you have your extroverts, Yui and Ritsu. Yui is in her own little world, amused by cute things and food. She's lazy, but charming. Ritsu is more hyper and crazy, always wanting to have fun. These characters together form delightful and inspiring simple friendships.


I didn't watch the series all at once, but spread out over a few months. At times it seemed to jump around a bit. But there is no complex plot. This is not going to be some amazingly professional review, criticizing every last detail about why I like or dislike K-On!. Instead, this is going to be my personal opinions informally thrown out there to tell people what this show is about. If you're looking for a step-by-step breakdown, don't read this review. Also, this review will not contain any spoilers.
K-On! revolves around the local school's Light Music Club, which is basically just a club where everyone in it is in a band and they create songs, play instruments, all that stuffs. When the first year of high school starts, 2 girls find out thatthe club is going to be disbanded due to lack of members (nobody is in the club), so they decide to take up the club and own it. Gradually more and more girls join and there ends up being 4 of them fairly early in the series. Later, a 5th, Azu-nyan, joins about half way through. Now, the main story of K-On! is... well... I guess it's about them trying to make music and become a well-known band or something...? But honestly it's about them eating cake and drinking tea. After school each day, they have their "practices" or "rehearsals," but they don't actually do a lot of practicing or rehearsing. Instead, they mainly sit around and talk while eating cake and drinking tea, which is usually very comical. The main aspect of this anime isn't necessarily about music, but more about being cute and funny. Yes there are music aspects as that's basically the whole plot and story of the show, but it's not as dominant as you'd think. For me, I'm glad. I liked just sitting back watching cute girls do cute and funny things, all while stuffing their faces with cake and tea. That is basically the summary of this whole anime: Cute girls do cute things while being funny, also while stuffing their faces with cake and tea. That's it. That's the show. Now, when they actually play songs and etc. and preform concerts, the music is awesome. The sound quality throughout the whole anime is very crisp and nice, and the songs are cutesy and very enjoyable. The characters are very enjoyable as well, as I said earlier they're all cute and do cute and funny things. I really liked Mio who was the shy and scaredy-cat one of the group. They all have their own unique personalities and each one of them plays a different instrument. Well, I guess that's the review.


Yes, I understand that this was a gigantic run on paragraph listing random facts about this series, but that's just what it came out to be. Again it's very informal and I'm just spewing out information about why I like this show, so there you go. You should definitely watch K-On!, because it's relaxing, cute, and thoroughly enjoyable. Unless you're looking for a deep plot or conflicts, because it has practically none of that.


10/10 - Would eat cake and drink tea again

What makes this anime interesting is their story as high school students, the cuteness of characters and the most important- the music. I like this anime because as a fellow musician, I can relate on what they are doing such as being able to play an instrument, working hard for practice until you can reach success. Just two words: Keion Rocks!!

K-ON! is one of those rare shows that features music as the over-arching theme. It can be a hit-or-miss, considering who it is targeting to and what your own preference of music is.
Story: 7
The series follows Hirasawa Yui and how she gets herself involved in the Light Music Club. Even though she has little to no musical talent, she joins the club as their lead guitarist. The show was set to be simple -- nothing too fancy and nothing too bizzare. The comedic part of the series is extremely light and nothing that will make you burst into tears, but that's my own preference.
Art &Animation: 7

Kyoto Animation found that making shows more "moe" like would bring in the viewer's attention -- so they did it. Again, like the plot of the story, nothing too fancy. Each character was drawn to look cute with not that many details. The art for the ending was a lot more detailed, and that would've gotten me a bit more attached to the series if it was like that. Moe art for me, ehhh. It's not something I would prefer, but it works.


Sound: 7

Again, music is all about preference. It is a hit-or-miss for you if you like pop music. There is a big risk in making a series solely on music, since you don't have much to fall back on. The songs were meant to be nonsensical and also added a small part of the comical element to the series. Try reading some of the titles of the songs featured in the series -- it can be a bit odd. The lyrics are no different. Nevertheless, just about every song they have made is catchy and enjoyable.


Character: 6

I don't know what it is about having 1 of every character:

Hirasawa Yui, the airhead and the main protagonist of the series. She gets the most development throughout the series, but it seems to lack at some aspects. (guitarist, singer)

Akiyama Mio, a timid girl where memes of her spreaded like wildfire (Just search up Moe Moe Kyun and you will know what i'm talking about). (Bassist, singer)

Kotobuki Tsumugi, the rich one out of them all that offers tea and cake just about every episode.(pianist)

Tainaka Ritsu, the tom-boyish character of the series. (drummist)

Nakano Azusa, the semi-serious character in the series only to revert into the fanservice cat cosplayer that everyone loves. (guitarist)


What do they all have in common? Their enjoyment of tea and cake while being extremely lax most of the time throughout the entire series... and being extremely moe. They all have a single specific characteristic that only they can have, leaving a lot to desire in character development. It develops a bit more in the second season, but this is just a review for the first.


Enjoyment: 6

It wasn't really a show that got me excited, or pumped to watch the next episode. It was more of a, "meh, i'll continue to see how it ends". It became repetitive and my enjoyment level slowly depleted as a result. When Azusa was introduced in the series, it gave me hope that it may get a bit more serious, but I was let down as she got more and more affiliated with the Houkago Tea Time band. 


Overall: 7

I am not saying this series was bad. The plot of the series was to get a bunch of girls together to play some music -- and they achieved that. After that, there wasn't much following it. If it's not music, you just follow their daily lives at school, which just about every anime has adopted for some reason.

If you want to expand your pool of music and want to just sit back and relax to a series that isn't taking itself too seriously, watch it. Otherwise, it's not something that you have to be extremely eager to see.

Story - 7
The story can be viewed in one of two ways:
1- Yui's quest to join the Light Music Club and the club's attempts at playing shows, improving etc which is present in few episodes.
2- A general following of the light music club's endeavours and their cutesy antics, this story being the more present one.
If you're looking for a strong story driven and episodic anime then this most likely won't be for you, whereas if you want an anime that doesn't require a lot of thinking and allows you to zone out or just put on when you want to have a laugh K-On! shouldbe right down your ally



Art - 7


The show's art isn't exactly great meaning it can be hard for it to stand out in a crowd but it is still nice to look at. The characters in the anime all tend to be easily distinguished from each other although during certain scenes such as when they are asleep the characters can be difficult to tell apart (especially Yui, Ritsu and Ui)


Similarly the character's designs (cute girls, big eyes etc) are pretty similar to those of other characters in other moe; also taking from its ability to stand out in a crowd



Characters - 7


Although the characters are most likely based on the archetypes of most moe characters you shouldn't let that put you off


All of the characters are easily likeable in K-On! with each of the main cast having their own role in drawing viewers in


Yui (guitarist and vocalist) plays the role the ditsy girl that provides the set ups for a majority of the funny moments and bounces off of Ritsu's character very well

-

Ritsu (drummer) is best compared to a tomboy as she enjoys playing the drums and scaring the other characters (mostly Mio)

-

Mio (bassist and vocalist) is the serious character that usually tries to keep the band on track. She's also quite the scaredy cat which sets her up for multiple scenes of other characters scaring her

-

--

Sawa Chan (teacher and advisor) acts as the club's advisor, she is more often than not shown as being a sweet charger l character that is loved by the students for her kindness and beauty however sometimes her character takes a full turn and acts more hostile due to her guitarist past



Sound - 8 (Dub sound)

The acting is also done well with the characters sounding pretty much as you'd expect:

Yui being high pitched and cutesy to match her ditsy personality.

-

Ritsu having an almost raspy voice to match her tomboy tendencies.

-

Mio and Asuza both having serious voices for the most part to compliment their work-then-play attitudes.

-

Mugi having a high 'wow everything is amazing' voice to match her habit of being happy 90% of the time and finding everything (including silverware cleaners) to be cool and interesting

-

Finely Sawa chan for the most part having a sweet voice letting her maintain her image of kind teacher, while also being able to switch to a volatile, raspy tone when letting her inner rock star shine



Enjoyment 7


Overall the show is pretty enjoyable if you enjoy anime that don't follow a strong plot and generally don't have a very episodic nature. While watching K-On! you can relax, turn off your brain and just mindlessly tune in, all while being provided with laughs.


You can also opt to be an active viewer, fully engulf yourself in the show and take in the show's small pieces of plot and receive a little bit more enjoyment from the anime



Overall - 7.2


In conclusion K-On! is quite enjoyable and is a good way to provide yourself with some laughs, it has likeable characters, catchy music and a nice art style so it'd be recommended that you watch it rather than take a pass on it.

K-On! Never in my wildest dreams did I think I'd enjoy an anime like this. Boy, oh boy.
Story 10/10
If you started watching K-on expecting an actual plot, then it is you who is lacking, not the anime. That's like going to a Michael Bay film and expecting to get a nuanced classical drama. It is a 10/10 story, precisely because there is no story or plot (or rather a minimal one at that). You can pick it up at any episode and follow along. Sometimes, you just want to kick off your shoes, cozy up under a blanket and watch a cute little anime, youknow? And I cannot overstate the importance of not having any romantic aspect in this show. Seriously, if they had done that, it would've been a 2/10 show for me. Moving on...


Character 10/10 & Art 10/10

Imagine the cutest and clumsiest little dog you can think of. Now turn that dog into a human. You have Hirasawa Yui.


How the hell can something be this cute! Props to KyoAni. With Clannad, Hyouka and Inu Yasha, they were already up high in my list. But now, with K-on, yeah... Yui's character and interaction designer, or maybe it was the manga artist who did this in the first place, you sir, are simply amazing. If it were up to me, r/aww would have nothing but K-on gifs and screenshots.


Watching the Hirasawa sisters interact is simply, healing. Hearing Yui say "Ui" is panacea.

They rank pretty high up in my top conversational duo list, after Araragi/Senjougahara, and Holo/Lawrence, and Hachiman/Haruno and Araragi/Shinobu, and Araragi/Tsuki, and... well, the Monogatari series is cheating. But you get the idea.


Not just that, Yui just friggin lights up any and every scene that she is in. An MC that actually grabs and shines in every possible moment? It's Yui. No one can compare here. She 'makes' the show. And keep in mind, I'm not taking anything away from the other characters here. They're all so friggin adorable. It's just that Yui ties everything together.


Sound 8/10

All you voice actors, you simply could not have done a better job. But for a music oriented anime, it could've had some better OST.


And finally, this anime might not be for everyone. People tend to expect different things from different shows for different reasons at different times. I was just frustrated by a couple of anime that I watched recently (Noragami, looking at you) and wanted to simply watch something where nothing happens. I'm really really glad I picked up K-On. Anyway, if you think, 'fun things are fun', you know what to do.


Say, "Moe Moe Kyuuun" and give in to happiness.

[STORY: 3/10]
"K-ON!" is not a very story-rich or enticing show. It wants to be a slice of life, but one that does little to tell a good story, which is something pretty important for this type of show to do, or it just gets boring fast. Cute girls doing everyday things isn't enough to keep me interested.
[ART: 7/10]
The art is above average and the character design is very well done, but that's all I can say. Nothing is spectacular about it that makes it stand out besides the carefully crafted cute characters.
[SOUND: 6/10]
Characters can be annoying and loud, but the voice actors do a goodjob at least. Music for openings is pretty enjoyable, but otherwise it's pretty mediocre.\n\n
[CHARACTER: 6/10]\n
There are some enjoyable characters and some lackluster and generic ones, but the character design is done very well, as I said earlier. Nothing much to say besides that.\n\n
[ENJOYMENT/OVERALL: 5/10]\n
"K-ON!" could've benefited from a more interesting series of events that strayed away from the generic "lets do club stuff and be high school kids" idea that a huge chunk of these slice of life shows try to replicate (and only a few get it right). It definitely has standout character design, but lacks in most other areas and really brings it down to an average rating.

Funny - Cute - Plotless
If these words are ones that don't leave any negative thoughts in your head, you'll probably enjoy K-On! quite a bit. It's a harmless show that has no real themes, morals, or plot of any kind. It's just a show that is all about having fun. Plain and simple.
Despite what you may think beforehand, the truth of the matter is that there is no plot. Yes, certain episodes have some small roadblock for certain characters, but really, there's mainly nothing going on plot-wise in this anime. I don't necessarily have a problem with that. Lucky Star has no plot, and yet,it is one of my favorite anime of all time. It works due to the humor and characters. When it comes to K-On!, the humor is pretty good for the most part. It definitely had me laughing at certain parts that were silly and stupid, but in a cute way. None of the humor deals with fanservice or adult jokes of any kind. It's very safe. Some people may not like that, but I greatly enjoyed every minute. One thing to keep in mind is that this isn't an anime where we get band songs every episode. There's probably three times where we see the characters play together. Just something to keep in mind.


It's no surprise to anyone that the animation and character designs are beautifully crafted. It's a show that looks as amazing as one would assume from KyoAni. 


Music here is definitely above average. I wouldn't cal it groundbreaking or anything. The songs played by the characters in the anime are all rock. They're well composed and everything, but not very memorable. Same with the OP and ED. Good, but slowly drifts away from the mind after watching an episode. 


The characters in K-On! are quite enjoyable too. They all have the traits you would assume from this type of anime. None really grow or transform that much throughout the series. Yui provides most of the comedy in the series. She's great. Her humor always hits a good note (no pun intended). One of my favorite jokes in the series deals with her and a guitar. I won't spoil it for you, but you'll know it when it happens. It's comedy gold. 


Did I enjoy K-On!? Yeah, but it never went over the hill for me. Sure, the humor works, but it isn't as strong as other slice of life anime. The characters were all enjoyable to watch, especially Yui. There weren't any characters I disliked or found annoying. With that said, they weren't anything to write home about ether. At the end of the day, this is a very good anime that will entertain you while watching it. With that said, it's not life-changing. I wouldn't recommend going out of your way to see it, but if you have nothing better to watch, it's a fun way to waste time and have some great laughs. Don't expect anything deep though.

K-On! Is a show that bases its appeal almost entirely in the relatability and evolution of its characters and its ability to create a light, fluffy atmosphere that viewers, given the time, can easily fall into. This review will cover the essential elements of the series using the component-by-component format and will be pertaining to only the first season, as I have not seen the second. Enjoy…
Story - 6: K-On’s story is enjoyable and light, which is all it really needs to be. The four girls come across an abandoned club in their high school, The Light Music Club, and the first two to stumbleupon it, Mio and Ritsu, act as recruiting agents. Once they find two more girls to make it qualify as a club, the story gets going (by its standards). The following events are fairly mild and, objectively, uninteresting. If you find yourself getting frustrated watching this show after a few episodes for this reason, just keep in mind that a gripping plot couldn’t be farther from the appeal of K-On!; rather, what the show goes for is a story that exists as nothing but a blueprint of sorts for the characters to interact with and make their own. This is where the life comes from in K-On!. Of course, characters will be covered in detail later in the review, but I bring it up now because the show’s story is just about pointless without them. You might be thinking “then why aren’t you giving the story a low-ass score if it is so weak on its own”, and you’d be right about it being weak on its own, but what’s important to keep in mind is that, while the characters are tailored to the story and make it unique and interesting, the story is likewise tailored toward the girls and takes adequate steps to make sure they are all put in scenarios that work well with their characters, which is not something that is necessarily simple at all, especially looking at it from an entertainment perspective. All things considered, K-On!’s story is adequate and lays a solid foundation for the more intriguing aspects of the show.


Art - 9: The animation and overall artistic flow of K-On! comes across as fairly simple and run-of-the-mill at first, particularly in its color scheme, I found. However, within a few more episodes, it becomes increasingly apparent that most of the way the show is animated is calculated and for a purpose. I noticed this almost bouncy feel in the manner of the girls’ design, particularly in Yui’s (which couldn’t be more fitting for her), and this helped in giving the girls’ antics, as well as the show as a whole, a more loving and airy tone unlike any other show I had seen. This is truly what hooked me about K-On! to begin with. Beyond this common factor, though, each girl in the band is animated a tad bit different, each having her animation tailored to her. Mio’s elegant, sturdy design is reflective of her level-headed, and almost mother-like nature toward the girls, Ritsu’s sketchy and almost sharp design is perfect for her off-the-wall shite, and Tsumugi is animated in a bubbly, lovey-dovey sort of style, representative of her role in the show as literally the girl who is made to be likeable beyond the point of being realistic. Aside from this, there is a general feel of completeness and attention to detail in all the settings the girls are in, contrasting greatly from the manga, which failed miserably in this department (as well as art in general). Another important thing to bring up about the settings and backgrounds is that they work to make up for the almost bland color schemes of the girl’s designs in some scenes. With that said, the art of K-On! is one of those previously mentioned aspects that brings the simplistic story to life, and is satisfactory in just about every regard.


Sound - 8: The soundtrack of K-On! is frankly unmemorable, which is a shame because every other aspect of this category is absolutely stellar. The OP and ending are perfect and reflect one of the balances that is one of the show’s goals to flesh out; the dichotomy of the girls’ seemingly simplistic and joyous time together (the opening) and their individual insecurities (the ending). Of course, considering this is the sound category, I would need to mention that the music of each the OP and outro are perfectly fitting respectively, as well. In addition, the voice actors match this quality with beaming energy and engagement being brought to each of their roles, thus creating a feeling of consistency in what this show is producing sound-wise, as well as making the characters feel more lively and fun beyond their writing and artistic design. Overall, the sound in K-On! is good enough to match the other aspects of the show, which, considering how highly I regard K-On!, is saying quite a lot.


Characters - 10: This is the selling point of the series, as K-On!’s characters retain a balance and chemistry that is yet to be matched by any slice-of-life, comedy-centric anime (or show, for that matter) that I’ve seen. Truthfully, the whole appeal of their bond as a band (almost rhymed) is that they build each other up and possess what each other lack, which varies from member to member. While this is faaaaaaaaaaaaar from the most original premise in existence, K-On!, if anything, is a testament to the argument that what a show (or any visual storytelling medium, for that matter) comes down to is not themes or premise, but the execution thereof. The way I see it, classic stories of all mediums, while built around solid themes, are not considered genius for their theme or message, but how the writer conveys it to the audience in a relatable and interesting manner; execution. Any oaf can say “my story is about friendship and the importance of bonds”, but not just anyone can make a cast of loveable characters using expert writing and art to make people give a shit about said message. I would summarize each character to further exemplify what I’m saying, but I’d rather just give an overview as to justify giving them a perfect 10, which is what I have done (and besides, I already covered in brief their personalities, excluding Azusa in the Art section). 


Enjoyment - 9: With a show that is so solid in virtually every category, I don’t think it comes as a surprise that my enjoyment of this series is high to say the least. The writing behind K-On! clearly takes into perspective the entertaining of its audience, as almost every scene involves the previously noted chemistry between characters, and the all-too-enjoyable art style. That said, the show did feel a bit slow in the beginning and I found myself constantly on edge over the fear that this was going to devolve into just another directionless, lackluster slice-of-life shitfest. However, as I continued, I found myself becoming strangely attached to the characters and the amazing amount of consistent badassery each had to offer. Later, as their insecurities became fleshed out, I felt sympathy for them, as well, which was the last piece in the puzzle of my complete admiration for the series. This caused me to acknowledge and respect how well this show knows its audience (including people who generally aren’t big slice-of-life fans). Virtually all tastes are considered and the show never pandered me too much with one thing. All in all, my enjoyment of K-On! is just about as solid as the show itself.


Overall - 9: K-On! is a show that does exactly what it set out to do and more. As I have only seen a few of the light-hearted anime of its nature, I don’t speak from a place of expertise, but I can recognize a good show when I see one. This series is fun, charming, and relatable and left me with a sense of completeness after viewing it. An important thing to note about the seemingly trite theme of friendship is that it is not an inherently harmful thing to incorporate into a show, and that it gets its bad rep simply for being used in media that generally is pretty repetitive and pointless. Thus, an action-oriented fan such as myself can easily find a solid foothold to enjoy this show on. Giving this show a fair chance would be in any anime fan’s best interest, and I hope I presented my thoughts on the matter in a manner that is clear, interesting, and informative.

Thanks for reading :3!!

Every genre has its entries that define how you should do a show of this genre. K-On! is the king of CGDCT/Slice of Life-Moe anime and shows what to expect of the genre, it gives a good idea of if the genre is for you.
Personally, I don’t need a great story of any story at all in a CGDCT anime or even basic things like character development. A good CGDCT-show can focus on its two main aspects: The cute girls and the cute things they are doing. Add some music of magic or any other fun thing, it should be fun, and you are onthe best way to make an entertaining and light-hearted piece of animation.


In K-On!, we follow four girls and their teacher living their carefree lives with drinking tea, eating cake and sometimes actually practicing for their band. There isn’t any bigger plot or conflict, they just handle different everyday situations with their different characters. Just like every Slice of Life show you’ve ever seen. 


Characters are the main aspect of any Slice of Life show, and K-On! Does a pretty good job here. Every girl has personality and are characterized enough to make them different from each other. We have the lazy, but caring girl, the adult, but shy girl, the over-energetic girl and the rich and calm girl. In my opinion, the teacher really stands out here, she tries to leave her wild youth behind and become the loved and respected teacher she wants to be, but she also wants to be friends with the girls and make daring costumes for them. The cast works well together and you end up loving them, not for a specific character, but for their interactions and friendship. Everything you could imagine them doing can be justified by one of the characters. They are having a training camp in a huge house at the beach? Mugi’s rich parents own it. Need some amazing costumes over night? Sawako can make them. Forgot to get permission for sleeping in school? Good thing we are friends with the president of the student council.


Music is always matter of taste, but I really liked it because it's light-heated and really suits the girls' personalities.


In conclusion, K-On! suffers from the same problems many CGDCT and SOL anime suffer from. If you the characters, the whole experience is ruined, because the whole show is focusing the characters. But if you start to like the characters and their quirks, you start enjoying every minute of the show, seeing their friendships develop and overcoming every problem they encounter. This season is in my opinion the weaker one of the two, in season 2 they do more interesting things and there is some conflict and character development.
